Thanh Hoa Province (THP) and Thanh Hoa City (Thanh Hoa). The 
Project 
is  classified  under  environmental  category  B  and

The Project seeks to enable an intermediary state of development 
for Thanh Hoa and support its socioeconomic enhancement. It is 
a  comprehensive  and  multisectoral  project  that  will  target  priority 
investments  and  create  a  suitable  and  sustainable  urban 
environment  for  Thanh  Hoa  and  strengthen  its  role  as  provincial 
capital.  The  Project  will  upgrade  Thanh  Hoa’s  urban  core, 
integrate  its  peri-urban  areas  and  further  develop  its  urban 
infrastructure  and  key  economic  sectors.  The  expected  outputs 
will  be:  (i)  an  improved  urban  road  network  (22  km)  and  urban 
basic services to link peri-urban urban villages with the city center 
along with complementary basic urban services; (ii) an expanded 
and  upgraded  water  supply  distribution  network,  including  about 
19  km  of  primary  and  secondary  water  supply  pipes  and 
connections  to  expand  the  service  to  peri-urban  areas  and 
replacement of 19 km of damaged pipes in the city; (iii) improved 
drainage  and  wastewater  treatment  in  Thanh  Hoa  through  the 
construction of 47 km of interceptors for sewerage and drainage, 
13  pumping  stations,  a  central  wastewater  treatment  pond,  and 
three  delocalized  wastewater  treatment  facilities  for  the  city 
general hospital; (iv) improved human resources and skills within 
local  utilities  and  line  departments  of  Thanh  Hoa  and  THP  and 
improved 
the  upgrading  of 
vocational  training  centers  and  other  capacity  building  initiatives;

The  country  strategy  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  for 
Viet  Nam’s  urban  sector  emphasizes  targeted  infrastructure 
investments  in  small-  and  medium-sized  towns  in  the  central

Thanh  Hoa  was  selected  for  this  comprehensive  socioeconomic 
development initiative based on social and economic criteria such 
as  urban  population  growth,  urban  and  rural  poverty  levels, 
economic development potential, and infrastructure needs. Thanh

industrial  and  social  sectors,  which  rank  well  below  the  national 
average according to various indexes. Thanh Hoa is challenged to

reverse  the  large  outflow  of  migration  from  both  Thanh  Hoa  city

poverty rate has been decreasing, Thanh Hoa will need to embark 
on development that is more socially inclusive. Such development 
should  target  vulnerable  groups  such  as  the  poor  in  peri-urban 
areas and should be carried out in combination with investments 
in  citywide  infrastructure,  human  resource  development,  and 
improved  urban  management.  The  social  assessment  also 
highlighted  the  need  for  private  sector  investment  to  create  job 
opportunities,  which  in  turn  will  improve  living  standards  and 
alleviate  poverty.  By  2020,  the  Project  will  directly  benefit  about 
75,000  people  living  in  urban  and  peri-urban  areas  though

2020  the  Project  will  indirectly  benefit  the  200,000  people  of

A. 

Performance Indicators and Analysis 

2. 
Over  the  last  two  decades  Viet  Nam  has  made  the  transition  from  centrally  planned  to 
market-oriented  economy  with  unprecedented  success.  From  1993  to  2006,  poverty 1  was 
reduced from 58.1% to 22.0%, gross domestic product (GDP) per capita increased from $288 to 
$722 in real terms, and economic output rose by an average of 7.5% annually. Between 2001 
and  2006,  domestic  and  international  trade  grew  at  an  average  annual  rate  of  17%,  while 
foreign direct investment increased by 650%. The Government recognizes the private sector’s 
pivotal  role  in  the  economy,  since  the  private  sector  generated  almost  90%  of  the  7.5  million 
jobs created during the same period. 

3. 
The  rapid  urbanization  of  Viet  Nam  is  a  reflection  of  the  country's  economic 
development. The urban growth rate has averaged 4.9% per annum over the last decade; about 
20  million  (23%)  of  the  current  population  of  85  million  now  live  in  urban  areas.  By  2020,  the 
urban component of the population is expected to nearly double to 40% as the population swells 
to  a  projected  104  million.  The  most  rapid  changes  are  occurring  in  the  two  largest  and  most 
dynamic cities—Ho Chi Minh City (5.2 million people) and Ha Noi (3.4 million people). The next 
tiers of secondary cities have achieved much slower growth rates. As a result, these major cities 
are becoming more congested due to in-migration and are facing increasingly serious social and 
environmental problems, such as chaotic spatial development and land speculation. Meanwhile, 
secondary  cities  that  are  located  beyond  the  political  and  economic  sphere  of  the  large  cities 
are  stagnating.  If  the  neglect  of  secondary  city  development  continues,  the  spatial  and 
economic  disparities  will  further  constrain  not  only  urban  development,  but  also  the  economic 
development of Viet Nam as a whole. 

4. 
The  Government,  through  its  Socio-Economic  Development  Plan  (SEDP  2006–2010), 
plans  to  develop  urban  areas  as  growth  centers  and  modernize  urban  infrastructure  to  attract 
investment,  improve  living  standards,  reduce  urban-rural  disparities,  and  ensure  sustainable 
development. Another plan, the Orientation Plan for Urban Development to 2020, also aims to 
promote  the  development  of  small-  and  medium-sized  cities  and  reduce  gaps  between  urban 
and rural areas. Similarly, separate orientation plans for water supply, urban drainage, and solid 
waste management and industrial waste aim to upgrade and expand, by 2020, a water supply 
system  to  ensure  100%  coverage;  drainage  and  sewerage  systems  to  ensure  80%  coverage; 
on-site  treatment  for  toxic  waste  for  enterprises;  and  collection  systems  for  solid  and  liquid 
wastes that can collect and dispose of at least 95% of urban and industrial wastes. 

5. 
In  parallel,  ADB’s  country  strategy  for  Viet  Nam’s  urban  sector  emphasizes  targeted 
infrastructure  investments  in  small-  and  medium-sized  towns  in  the  central  region  and  along 
economic corridors, with the objective of reducing migration to the large metropolitan cities. This 
will  require large  investments  in  infrastructure; decentralized  and  improved  urban  governance;

The  main  challenges  facing  secondary  cities  arise  from  a  lack  of  urban  infrastructure 
investments and the limited ability of local governments to provide reliable and affordable urban 
services. Missing links in the road network, obsolete water supply pipes and high water losses, 
flooding and clogged drains, and disposal of untreated waste constrain the productive capacity 
of secondary cities and make these cities less competitive and livable. The lack of infrastructure 
and limited capacity to manage urban services further discourages external investments that are 
critical to economic development and growth. To date, the Government has targeted 11 class II 
secondary  cities2 that  have  been  promoted  as  target  cities  for  development  to  limit  growth  in 
Hanoi  and  Ho  Chi  Minh  City.  ADB  is,  therefore,  targeting  its  assistance  at  this  class  II  group. 
Assistance  will  include  investments  to  upgrade  and  expand  urban  infrastructure,  and  “soft” 
investments  in  capacity  building,  institutional  reform,  and  participatory  development.  ADB  will 
collaborate with development partners and the private sector.

B. 

Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 

10. 
Thanh Hoa aims to become a regional hub and service center for new investments in the 
province, with the goal of achieving class I status by 2015. To achieve these goals, Thanh Hoa 
needs  to  capitalize  on  its  strengths,  overcome  its  weaknesses,  and  minimize  threats  to  its 
development.  During  project  preparation,  the  project  preparatory  technical  assistance  (PPTA) 
consultant  indicated  that  Thanh  Hoa’s  key  competitive  advantages  are  its  location  along  main 
transportation  routes,  its  capacity  to  expand  spatially,  and  its  proximity  to  economically 
developing areas such as Bim Son, Nghi Son, and Sam Son, natural resources (for mining), and 
natural landscapes (for tourism). Thanh Hoa’s best development opportunities lie in the areas of 
tourism  (cultural  heritage  and  natural  resources)  and  industry.  Its  weaknesses  are  poor  urban 
infrastructure,  unfavorable  demographic  and  labor  conditions  (out-migration,  low  productivity, 
low  skills,  and  skills  mismatch),  and  weak  human  resource  capacity.  The  main  threat  is 
competition  from  fellow  provincial  capitals  Ninh  Binh  and  Vinh  for  the  status  of  North  Central 
Viet Nam's main regional hub. These cities, which are the capitals of Thanh Hoa’s neighboring 
provinces Ninh Binh and Nghe An, could potentially replace Thanh Hoa as the primary service 
center for THP. 

11. 
Spatial  Location  and  Linkages.  Lying  150  km  south  of  Ha  Noi,  Thanh  Hoa  is 
accessible to Ha Noi, yet far enough away to ensure its own local economic development. It is 
located  along  major  transportation  networks  and  is  within  easy  reach  of  the  industrial 
development town of Bim Son (15 km to the north), the tourist town of Sam Son (16 km to the 
east), and the special industrial zone of Nghi Son (60 km to the south). The city center needs 
upgrading, particularly the central business area where the National Highway A1 intersects Le 
Loi Avenue. The construction of a new bridge crossing the Ma River is another pressing need. 
The  outlying  peri-urban  areas  have  economic  potential,  yet  are  not  well-utilized  because  they 
are poorly linked to the city center. For example, urban villages in the southwest of Thanh Hoa 
are  engaged  in  stone  processing,  handicraft  making,  and  bronze-drum  making.  Tourism  sites 
(Ham Rong and Mat Son), small and medium-sized enterprises, and historic sites (such as the 
2,500-year-old Dong Son archaeological site) are scattered and are not spatially integrated with 
the  urban  core.  Thanh  Hoa’s  future  development  needs  to  progressively  reach  these  urban 
villages, toward the east and south to expand over about 150 km2, with a future population of 
500,000.  

12. 
Key  Economic  Sectors:  Industrial  Development  and  Tourism.  Thanh  Hoa’s  main 
areas  of  potential  economic  development  are  industry  and  tourism.  In  addition  to  the  existing 
industrial  zones  of  Le  Mon,  Tay  Bac  Ga,  and  Dinh  Huong,  which  are  located  within  the  city 
boundaries, the main industries are extractive mining (stone, marble, kaolin, cement) and basic 
processing  industries  (especially  seafood).  These  industries  have  absorbed  some  of  the  local

demands of these industries. New industrial zones have been planned in Hoang Hoa district to 
the north and Quang Xuong district in the south to further capitalize on the availability of natural 
resources.  The  tourism  sites  of  Ham  Rong  (ecotourism  and  limestone  scenery),  Dong  Son 
(archaeology), and Mat Son (handicraft and stone villages) suffer from poor access and limited 
or  no  tourism  amenities.  These  sites  are  largely  untouched,  although  private  companies  have

Thanh  Hoa,  and  Hoang  Hoa  beach  to  the  north  are  within  close  reach  of  Ha  Noi,  but  receive 
tourists only during 3 months of the year. THP and Thanh Hoa have not been able to develop 
synergies to capitalize on the potential of these sites because of the interrelated issues of major 
infrastructure gaps, limited human resource capacity, and a poor regulatory framework.

15.  Water  Supply.  Piped  water  supply  coverage  is  about  60%,  while  the  remaining 
population  uses  shallow  wells;  nonrevenue  water  is  about  36%.  Thanh  Hoa  has  a  24-hour

urban area and 70 lcd in peri-urban areas. The average daily water demand is about 45,000 m3 
per day while current production is 30,000 m3 per day, serving Thanh Hoa, Sam Son, and five 
other  townships.  By  improving  the  piped  water  network  (replacing  pipes,  repairing  leaks, 
reducing nonrevenue water), as well as the management efficiencies of the Thanh Hoa Water 
Supply  Company  (THWSC),  more  Thanh  Hoa  residents  will  be  able  to  access  reliable  piped 
water. 

16. 
Drainage  and  Sewerage.  Drainage  is  problematic  as  Thanh  Hoa’s  topography  is  flat 
and  up  to  one-third  of  the  city  is  flooded  during  the  rainy  season.  The  partially  completed 
drainage  system  cannot  prevent  frequent  flash  floods.  There  is  no  wastewater  treatment  in 
Thanh Hoa. The absence of an adequate wastewater collection system leads people to dispose 
wastewater  directly  into  canals  and  waterways,  creating  pollution  and  public  health  hazards. 
There  is  a  need  to  upgrade  Thanh  Hoa’s  drainage  system  as  well  as  treat  the  wastewater 
before  disposal.  The  Project  will  improve  the  management  of  the  Urban  Environmental 
Company (URENCO). 

17. 
Out-Migration  from  Thanh  Hoa  Province  and  City.  The  current  demographic  trend 
indicates  a  shift  in  population  growth  and  significant  out-migration,  both  for  THP  and  Thanh 
Hoa. THP is one of the most densely populated provinces in Viet Nam. It is expected that within 
the next 10 years there could be a labor surplus of 700,000 based on an annual growth rate of 
3.2%. On the other hand, Thanh Hoa, with a population of 200,000, has a growth rate of 1.9% 
per  year,  but  still  could  lose  over  70,000  people  to  migration.  If  this  trend  continues,  out-
migration  from  THP  will  increase,  but  not  necessarily  to  Thanh  Hoa. Training  the  workforce in

challenge to retaining a productive workforce. 

18. 
A Low-Skilled Workforce and Capacity to Provide Urban Services. Currently, private 
investors are not investing in Thanh Hoa because of major infrastructure gaps and poor human 
resource  capacity.  Although  Thanh Hoa  has  a near  universal  secondary-level  graduation  rate, 
only  18%  of  the  population  has  received  any  tertiary  education  or  professional  training.  There 
are  6,000  students  in  THP,  distributed  over  15  continuing  education  centers,  20  vocational 
training institutions, and one university, Hong Duc. However, there is a gap between the skills 
supplied  and  those  required,  particularly  in  the  areas  of  general  administration,  language, 
communications,  and  management  skills  to  promote  tourism  and  industrial  development.  In 
order  to  improve  Thanh  Hoa’s  competitiveness  and  reduce  migration  out  of  THP  and  Thanh 
Hoa, the skills of the labor force must be improved through targeted investments  in education 
and training.  

19. 
Institutional  Aspects  of  Urban  Infrastructure  Management  and  Provision.  The 
causes  of  inefficient  infrastructure  are  multifaceted  but  are  rooted  in  the  lack  of  a  regulatory 
framework for infrastructure service provision. These include: (i) inadequate financing and cost 
recovery  mechanisms  for  capital  and  operating  expenditures;  (ii)  existence  of  policy, 
institutional,  and  structural  bottlenecks  that  deter  private  investment  to  finance  urban 
infrastructure; (iii) limited human resource capacity to plan, operate, and manage urban assets 
and provide urban services; and (iv) a lack of capacity to regulate the provision of infrastructure 
services.  The  need  for  improved  capacity  will  not  only  be  addressed  within  THWSC  and 
URENCO, but also in line departments within the Thanh Hoa and THP people's committees.

improve the infrastructure of the 2,000 m2 Thanh Hoa Museum; (b) upgrade the

24. 
Integrated Planning and Design. The Project seeks to integrate spatial and functional 
links,  which  will  comprise  targeted  investments  in  infrastructure  (urban  roads,  water  supply, 
drainage, and wastewater treatment), human resource development, and institutional reform to 
enable Thanh Hoa to develop tourism and industry, as its key economic sectors. It will link three 
broad  investments  comprising  core  urban  environment  upgrading,  integrated  peri-urban 
development,  and  investments  in  key  economic  sectors,  while  addressing  infrastructure  gaps 
and institutional bottlenecks. The proposed Project will finance an initial work program under the 
Master Plan, building on existing infrastructure and competitive advantages to jumpstart Thanh 
Hoa’s  economic  development.  The  integration  of  various  project  components  will  result  in  an

This integration will promote sustainable development in the project area and help achieve the 
project  objective  of  transforming  Thanh  Hoa  into  a  competitive  and  livable  city.  The  Project's 
secondary-city  development  model,  if  successful,  could  be  replicated  elsewhere  in  Viet  Nam 
and the Greater Mekong Subregion. The introduction of aesthetic urban design elements such

heritages  are  essential  to  creating  an  “image”  of  Thanh  Hoa,  which  has  a  huge  tourism 
potential. The City Development Strategy for Thanh Hoa in a Regional Context,9 a complementary

Hoa's  role  within  the  regional  "growth  triangle"  that  includes  Xam  Neua  in  the  Lao  People’s 
Democratic Republic to the west, Vinh to the south, and Hanoi to the north. The study will define 
the  roles  of  the  public  and  private  sectors,  as  well  as  civil  society  in  supporting  a  long-term

C. 

Economic Aspects 

49. 
The project components are mutually reinforcing and have positive externalities. Overall 
returns to project investment are likely to be greater than the sum of the individual components. 
The proposed Project is a comprehensive and multisectoral project that will direct investments 
to priority areas and create a sustainable urban environment for Thanh Hoa and strengthen its 
role of provincial capital by becoming an urban service center for the province. 

50. 
For the road development component, the Project will yield a net present value of some 
$8.6  million  and  an  economic  internal  rate  of  return  (EIRR)  of  17.2%.  The  sensitivity  analysis 
shows a relatively stable EIRR, mostly affected if benefits are delayed by a year, which would 
yield  an  EIRR  of  15.4%.  For  the  water  supply  component,  the  results  of  the  base-case  EIRR 
analysis  show  an  EIRR  of  14.9%.  Sensitivity  analysis  is  acceptable,  with  a  reduction  of  about 
1% in the EIRR. For the drainage component, it is projected that about 143,000 people will live 
in  the  urban  core  by  2025,  of  which  at  least  50,000  could  be  affected  by  flooding.  Pollution 
would continue to build up in urban and nearby waterways, providing a significant health hazard 
to inhabitants and visitors alike. The Project will not eliminate flooding entirely but it will reduce 
the  severity  and  duration  of  flooding.  For  the  human  resource  development  component,  the 
economic rationale for subcomponent selection is based on the expected benefits of vocational 
training on tourism and industrial development. For the tourism component, Thanh Hoa expects 
49,900 additional visitors in the first year of the Project, rising to 342,000 in 2035. The EIRR is 
estimated  to  be  19%  and  is  most  sensitive  to  a  reduction  by  20%  in  tourists’  spending,  which 
yields an EIRR of 16%. Lastly, EIRR is 16% if average daily expenditures by tourists are less 
than  20%.  The  outline  of  the  economic  analysis  is  in  Appendix  10  and  the  full  version  in 
Supplementary Appendix K.

A. 

Overview of the Viet Nam Urban Context 

THANH HOA URBAN SECTOR ANALYSIS 

1. 
For  the  past  two  decades,  Viet  Nam  has  made  the  transition  from  a  centrally  planned 
economy  to  a  market-oriented  system  with  unprecedented  success.  This  transition  has  been 
made possible by political stability, government commitment for economic reforms, and targeted 
programs  to  provide  basic  public  infrastructure.  From  1993  to  2006,  poverty  declined  from 
58.1% to 22.0%, gross domestic product per capita increased from $288 to $622, and economic 
output  rose  by  an  average  of  7.5%  per  year. 1 Agriculture's  share  in  total  economic  output 
declined from 30% to 21% while manufacturing and services rose from 70% to  79%. Between 
2001 and 2006, industrial production and domestic and international trade grew at an average 
annual  rate  of  17%,  while  foreign  direct  investment  increased  by  650%.  The  Government  is 
increasingly  recognizing  the  private  sector’s  pivotal  role  in  economic  development  and  job 
creation. Preliminary estimates indicate that the private sector generated almost 90% of the 7.5 
million  jobs  created  during  the  5  years  to  2005,  of  which  64%  were  generated  by  small 
enterprises. 

2. 
Economic  development  is  also  reflected  in  the  rapid  growth  of  urban  areas.  With  a 
population of 85 million, only 19.6 million (23%) live in urban areas, while 65.4 million (77%) live 
in rural areas. However, this is rapidly changing. As the rate of urban population growth rate has 
averaged  5.4%  per  year  during  the  past  10  years,  it  is  expected  that  by  2020  the  urban 
population  will  comprise  41.6  million  (40%)  of  Viet  Nam’s  projected  population  of  104  million. 
However,  most  of  the  urban  growth  is  occurring  in  the  metropolises  of  Ho  Chi  Minh  City 
(population  5.2  million)  and  Ha  Noi  (population  3.1  million),  followed  by  Hai  Phong  and  Da 
Nang. The next tier of secondary cities2 is experiencing lower growth rates. As a result, major 
metropolises are receiving large inflows of migration, are becoming more congested , and are 
experiencing  increasingly  serious  social  and  environmental  problems.  At  the  same  time, 
secondary  cities  are  stagnating.  If  the  neglect  of  secondary  city  development  continues,  the 
spatial and economic disparities will further constrain not only urban development, but also Viet 
Nam’s overall economic development. 

3. 
The  main  challenges  facing  secondary  cities  stem  from  obsolete  urban  infrastructure 
and  lack  infrastructure  investments,  particularly  in  road  networks,  water  supply,  environmental 
treatment,  solid  waste 
sanitation  (drainage,  sewerage,  hazardous  waste,  wastewater 
management, and air pollution control), power, and communications. The lack of infrastructure 
discourages  outside  investments  that  are  critical  to  catalyzing  economic  development  and 
growth.  The  causes  are  multifaceted  but  interrelated,  and  include  but  are  not  limited  to: 
(i)  inadequate  financing  and  cost  recovery  for  capital  expenditures  and  operation  and 
maintenance;  (ii)  the  existence  of  policy,  institutional,  and  structural  bottlenecks  that  deter 
private  investment  that  could  free  up  scarce  government  resources;  and  (iii)  limited  human 
resource  capacity  to  plan,  operate,  and  manage  urban  assets  and  provide  urban  services. 
Alleviating  these  constraints  has  proved  difficult  as  population  increases  have  put  additional 
pressure on public services provision, reduced living standards, and polluted the environment. 
The  absence  of  strong  and  effective  governance  and  broad-based  support  and  participation 
from  civil  society  (including  the  private  sector,  community  groups,  and  societal  organizations) 
has compounded these problems.

Regulatory Framework and Strategies for Urban Development 

4. 
The  lack  of  an  enforceable  regulatory  framework  for  urban  infrastructure  provision  as 
well  as  effective  institutions  has  constrained  effective  and  efficient  infrastructure  service 
provision.  Since  1990  the  Government  has  introduced  policies  and  reforms  to  improve  the 
efficiency  of  the  urban  sector  and  promote  urban  development 3  which  aim  to  (i)  promote 
balanced and sustainable economic growth between regions, (ii) develop urban areas to create 
more  jobs  and  improve  living  standards,  and  (iii)  strengthen  environmental  protection  and 
ensure  a  healthy  environment.  The  Government  has  endorsed  a  series  of  orientation  plans 
related to urban development.4 

5. 
Currently  there  are  11  secondary  cities,  designated  as  class  II  cities,  that  have  been 
promoted  as  target  cities  to  limit  growth  in  Ha  Noi  and  Ho  Chi  Minh  City.  As  a  part  of  ADB’s 
urban development assistance strategy for Viet Nam, class II candidates are being targeted for 
assistance  and  investments  to  upgrade  and  expand  urban  infrastructure  along  with  “soft” 
investments in capacity building, institutional reform, and societal participation. The assistance 
is  also  designed  to  attract  development  partners,  the  private  sector,  and  other  sources  of 
funding  to  further  enhance  city  development.  For  selection  purposes,  several  criteria  were 
developed:  (i)  urban  population  growth,  (ii)  urban  and  rural  poverty  level,  (iii)  economic 
development  potential,  (iv)  infrastructure  needs,  and  (v)  special  features  that  could  potentially 
be developed (e.g., tourism, cultural heritage, sustainable industrial development, environmental 
features).  Based  on  these  criteria,  Thanh  Hoa  City  was  selected  as  a  model  project  for 
socioeconomic development.

The current demographic trend indicates a shift in population growth and migration, both 
for THP and Thanh Hoa. Thanh Hoa Province is one of the most densely populated provinces in 
Viet Nam. It is expected that within the next 10  years there  will be a labor surplus of 700,000 
because the population is growing at an annual rate of 3.2%. On the other hand, Thanh Hoa, 
with a population of 200,000, has an annual population growth rate of only 1.9 %. If this trend 
continues,  out-migration  from  THP  will  increase,  but  not  necessarily  to  Thanh  Hoa,  which 
means that it will struggle to attract additional population. The tentative conclusion, therefore, is 
that THP will supply migrants not to Thanh Hoa, but to the large metropolises of Ha Noi and Ho 
Chi Minh City. Although Thanh Hoa has nearly a universal secondary-level graduation rate, only 
18% of the population has a tertiary education or professional training. There are 15 continuous 
training centers, 20 vocational training institutions, and one university—Hong Duc in Thanh Hoa 
(6,000 students). Therefore, to improve Thanh Hoa’s competitiveness and attract migration, the 
productivity of the labor force must be improved through education and skills training. 

10. 
Urban  infrastructure  facilities  are  in  general  deficient.  For  urban  roads,  the  main

roads  leading  from  the  city  center  to  the  urban  periphery  and  non-urban  areas  in  the  city  are

poor road conditions. There are currently 54 km of roads. Urgent priorities for Thanh Hoa are to 
complete  missing  links  in  the  road  network  connecting  secondary  roads,  improve  access  to 
handicraft villages and tourism sites, and improve operation and maintenance of road surfaces.

Samson, and five other  townships. Drainage is problematic as Thanh Hoa’s topography is flat

that  in  some  areas,  only  40%  of  households  have  latrines.  There  are  neither  wastewater

I. 

POVERTY ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 

A.  Linkages to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy  
 
Viet  Nam’s  Socio-Economic  Development  Plan  2006–2010  aims  to  achieve  industrialized  country  status  by  2020.  The 
country's  poverty  reduction  strategy  is  included  in  the  plan.  The  strategy  notes  that  increased  private  investment  and 
international economic integration are crucial to creating jobs, improving living standards, and alleviating poverty. As Viet Nam 
becomes more urbanized, cities are playing larger roles as economic growth centers and nodes of development. However, for 
this to happen public infrastructure must be improved through broad-based participation from the private sector and society, 
taking into account vulnerable groups, ethnic minorities, and women. ADB’s urban sector strategy for Viet Nam emphasizes 
targeted infrastructure investments in small and medium-sized towns along economic corridors and thereby diverts migration 
away from the large cities of Ha Noi and Ho Chi Minh City.  
 
Thanh  Hoa  Province  (THP),  the  third  largest  province  in  Viet  Nam,  has  an  area  of  11,168  square  kilometers  (km2)  and  a 
population  of  3.7  million,  of  which  only  9.8%  live  in  urban  areas.  THP  is  the  second  poorest  province  in  Viet  Nam,  with  a 
poverty level of 36% (2006) and a gross domestic product (GDP) per capita that is half the national average. THP also has 
the  second  highest  population  density  among  Viet  Nam  provinces.  The  capital,  Thanh  Hoa  City  (Thanh  Hoa),  located  160 
south  of  Ha  Noi,  has  a  population  of  197,500  (2006)  with  a  low-skilled  workforce  and  obsolete  urban  infrastructure  —
particularly  road  networks,  water  supply  and  sanitation  facilities,  and  wastewater  treatment  facilities.  The  increasing 
population  density,  poverty  incidence,  and  lack  of  employment  in  rural  areas  is  gradually  transforming  agricultural  land  to 
urban  use  in  the  peripheral  areas  and  putting  pressure  on  Thanh  Hoa’s  existing  infrastructure  and  services,  as  well  as 
creating pockets of poverty in the urban core due  mainly to the arrival of migrants. By addressing urgent development needs, 
the  proposed  Project  will  enable  Thanh  Hoa  to  realize  its  vision  of  becoming  a  dynamic,  competitive,  bankable  and  livable 
secondary  city  and  one  of  north-central  Viet  Nam's  key  commercial  hubs. The  Project  will,  among  other  things,  develop  an 
integrated  road  network  connecting  the  city  center  with  its  peri-urban  areas,  which  will  lead  to  savings  in  travel  time  and 
shorten the distance between suppliers and markets; support water supply, sewerage, and drainage improvements to improve 
productivity,  public  health,  and  the  general  well-being  of  the  population;  improve  job  skills  in  key  sectors  and  increase  the 
productivity  of  the  local  workforce  in  order  to  increase  incomes  and  make  Thanh  Hoa  more  competitive  as  a  whole;  and 
develop  the  local  tourism  industry.  In  addition  to  the  ensuing  investment  loan,  a  Japan  Fund  for  Poverty  Reduction  grant 
project will facilitate investments in smaller-scale, community infrastructure and services in poor urban and peri-urban areas. 
By  providing  access  to  capital  assets  and  a  source  of  income  for  individuals  or  community  groups  operating  small-scale 
businesses and affordable basic urban services for individuals who currently lack access to such services, this grant will help 
maximize the overall poverty and socioeconomic impacts of the larger investment Project. 
 
B.  Poverty Analysis                                                                                    Targeting Classification: General intervention 
  
Key Issues  
In  general,  residents  in  peri-urban  areas  are  poorer  than  residents  in  the  urban  core.  The  lack  of  infrastructure  and  basic 
services and physical isolation, (particularly in peri-urban areas that lack transportation access to the city), exacerbated by low 
labor  productivity,  ill  health,  and  poor  job  skills  were  considered  the  main  causes  of  poverty  in  the  peri-urban  areas.  Low 
incomes and a lack of jobs are causing people to migrate from Thanh Hoa to more competitive cities both in Viet Nam and 
abroad.  While  the  secondary  education  graduation  rate  is  high  (77%),  the  vocational  or  tertiary  education  enrollment  levels 
are  low  (17%).  With  the  share  of  agriculture  in  Thanh  Hoa’s  total  economic  output  on  the  decline,  the  manufacturing  and 
service sectors  (particularly tourism and trade) are assuming increased importance in creating jobs. Thanh Hoa will need to 
embark  on  socially  inclusive  development  that  targets  poor  peri-urban  dwellers  and  vulnerable  groups  and  promotes 
investment in citywide infrastructure, human resource development, and improved urban management.

that the poverty rate in urban wards was about 13.6%. The assessment concluded that, although the poverty rate has been

The Government of Viet Nam aims to alleviate migration pressure on Hanoi and Ho-Chi-

automobile  assembly  and  components  in  Binh  Son  and  Nigh  Son,  and  hydropower  in  the

infrastructure  investments  in  small  and  medium-sized  towns  in  the  central  region  and  along 
economic  corridors.  A  lack  of  urban  infrastructure  investments  is  seen  as  one  of  the 
weaknesses  facing  secondary  cities.  Thanh  Hoa’s  goal  is  now  to  achieve  class  I  status  and
